newsitem.title: CHINA: China media mum on conviction of princeling.
newsitem.headline: China media mum on conviction of princeling.

text.p: China's state media made no mention on Saturday of a suspended death sentence handed down to the son of an influential party official for economic crimes.

A Beijing court has convicted Zhou Beifang, former chairman of Hong Kong-listed affiliates of the giant state-owned Capital Iron and Steel Corporation, as part of China's highly-publicised anti-graft campaign launched last year, a Chinese source said.
Zhou's sentence was one of the heaviest handed down to a so-called "princeling", the popular sobriquet applied to the children of China's ruling party elite, who enjoy wide influence.
No other details of the case were available.
Major newspapers and the official Xinhua news agency were mum on Zhou's conviction and court officials could not be reached for comment.
In China, suspended death sentences are often commuted to life imprisonment after two years.
Last month, prosecutors filed charges of corruption against 30 people, including Zhou and two former officials of the Beijing city government.
Chinese courts frequently impose the death penalty in major corruption cases.
The Zhous have close ties to the family of paramount leader Deng Xiaoping.
Zhou was detained in February, 1995, forcing his father, Zhou Guanwu, to resign as chairman and Communist Party secretary of Capital Iron and Steel Corporation.
Corruption was virtually eliminated in the years after the communists came to power in 1949, but has staged a comeback along with economic reforms in the past 17 years.
Communist Party chief and state president Jiang Zemin has declared war on corruption, warning that the scourge was a virus that threatened the party.
